instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ON CRITICAL UPDATE <CHIP>U4200</CHIP> VERY HOT
threads.message:
Good day guys, am currently having a 15 inch board with critical update error and crashes , I followed up to <CHIP>U4200</CHIP>, ( by the way, I have had an issue like this I past, which I was able to solve, thanks to [USER=682]@2informaticos[/USER] ,  just turns out to be a different cause  this time ) the <CHIP>U4200</CHIP> (Berkelium) gets very hot, so I want to replace it , but am not sure if I can take from the same donor board and get the machine to work, please help guys
Also on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_SOC_PMU</SIGNAL> I get 0.077 on diode mode , which is slightly lower than a functional board , but surprisingly, I get 3.3V still on that line, though <CHIP>U4200</CHIP> gets really hot

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ON CRITICAL UPDATE <CHIP>U4200</CHIP> VERY HOT
threads.message:
Do you get all voltages controlled by <CHIP>U4200</CHIP>?

Did you try external monitor, disconnecting internal LCD?
This way can discard an ALS/CAM issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ON CRITICAL UPDATE <CHIP>U4200</CHIP> VERY HOT
threads.message:
Yes I do  get the voltages controlled by <CHIP>U4200</CHIP>, please help me answer the part of the the chip getting hot and the replacement option. Also about about how diode mode measurement is lower than a reference board . 
Thanks for your time

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ON CRITICAL UPDATE <CHIP>U4200</CHIP> VERY HOT
threads.message:
"Did you try external monitor, disconnecting internal LCD?"
???

<CHIP>U4200</CHIP> can get hot because of excessive current consum of other chip.
Lower reading in diode mode can be caused by <CHIP>U4200</CHIP>, or something else connected there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ON CRITICAL UPDATE <CHIP>U4200</CHIP> VERY HOT
threads.message: I tried an external display with internal screen disconnected , but the result is the same, and <CHIP>U4200</CHIP> still gets extremely hot, can I replace it ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ON CRITICAL UPDATE <CHIP>U4200</CHIP> VERY HOT
threads.message:
Change <CHIP>U4200</CHIP>.
But shouldn't be the culprit, if it generates all the voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ON CRITICAL UPDATE <CHIP>U4200</CHIP> VERY HOT
threads.message: Its has no firmware ? Also where else can I check before replacing <CHIP>U4200</CHIP> ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ON CRITICAL UPDATE <CHIP>U4200</CHIP> VERY HOT
threads.message:
If you still get critical update error on external monitor (internal disconnected), then is not ALS/CAM issue.
There are few things more to check, mentioned by dukefawks; you should have that information saved on your PC.

Not sure if <CHIP>U4200</CHIP> firmware is board dependant, but shouldn't be a problem if you pick it from same donor board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ON CRITICAL UPDATE <CHIP>U4200</CHIP> VERY HOT
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ON CRITICAL UPDATE <CHIP>U4200</CHIP> VERY HOT
threads.message:
Just received a Mac from eBay very similar to this one.. Couldn't get around critical update. No touch bar or keyboard backlight. 
Clean everywhere but when looking under <CHIP>U4200</CHIP> I noticed junk around pins 36-84 so I replaced from a donor board. 
Mac took a while to boot the first time but everything worked and no more critical update error. 
Not sure if this was the same mac.. but this definitely solved the problem for me.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ON CRITICAL UPDATE <CHIP>U4200</CHIP> VERY HOT
